user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_MD5_update:
```c
void
MHD_MD5_update (struct Md5Ctx *ctx,
                const uint8_t *data,
                size_t length)
{
  unsigned int bytes_have; /**< Number of bytes in the context buffer */

  mhd_assert ((data != NULL) || (length == 0));

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (0 == length)
    return; /* Shortcut, do nothing */
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

  /* Note: (count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE-1))
           equals (count % MD5_BLOCK_SIZE) for this block size. */
  bytes_have = (unsigned int) (ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1));
  ctx->count += length;

  if (0 != bytes_have)
  {
    unsigned int bytes_left = MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - bytes_have;
    if (length >= bytes_left)
    {     /* Combine new data with data in the buffer and
             process the full block. */
      memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have,
              data,
              bytes_left);
      data += bytes_left;
      length -= bytes_left;
      md5_transform (ctx->H, ctx->buffer);
      bytes_have = 0;
    }
  }

  while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length)
  {   /* Process any full blocks of new data directly,
         without copying to the buffer. */
    md5_transform (ctx->H, data);
    data += MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
    length -= MD5_BLOCK_SIZE;
  }

  if (0 != length)
  {   /* Copy incomplete block of new data (if any)
         to the buffer. */
    memcpy (((uint8_t *) ctx->buffer) + bytes_have, data, length);
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are invariant constants and therefore none that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Specifically:

- The preprocessor conditional #ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE is a compile-time directive, not a runtime controlling expression governed by Rule 14.3.
- if (0 == length) depends on the function parameter length (not a compile-time constant).
- if (0 != bytes_have) depends on bytes_have, which is computed from ctx->count & (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE - 1) (not a compile-time constant for general inputs).
- if (length >= bytes_left) depends on runtime values length and bytes_left (bytes_left depends on bytes_have and MD5_BLOCK_SIZE).
- while (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE <= length) is not an invariant constant: it depends on the runtime value length (MD5_BLOCK_SIZE is a constant but comparing a variable to a constant does not make the controlling expression invariant).
- if (0 != length) depends on the runtime variable length.
- The mhd_assert((data != NULL) || (length == 0)) is a macro invocation; its argument is not a compile-time constant (it depends on the parameters passed) and the macro may expand differently in build configurations — it is not an invariant controlling expression in the sense of Rule 14.3.

None of the above control expressions are constant/invariant at compile time (e.g., while(1) or if(0)), nor are there do-while constructs covered by the stated exceptions. Therefore no code fragments in this function appear to violate Rule 14.3 and none need further investigation for invariant controlling expressions.
